data.title: Dmitri Shostakovich: Symphony No. 15, Suite Op. 145a, Novorossiisk Chimes Op.111b
data.meta_description:
Dmitri Shostakovich: Symphony No. 15, Suite Op. 145a, Novorossiisk Chimes Op.111b by Eduard Serov, Sergei Kopčák, František Vajnar, Arvīds Jansons, released 01 May 2016

1. Symphony No. 15 in A Major, Op. 141		I. Allegretto
2. Symphony No. 15 in A Major, Op. 141		II. Adagio - Largo - Adagio - Largo
3. Symphony No. 15 in A Major, Op. 141		III. Allegretto
4. Symphony No. 15 in A Major, Op. 141		IV. Adagio - Allegretto - Adagio - Allegretto
5. Suite on Words by Michelangelo, Op. 145a		No. 1: Truth
6. Suite on Words by Michelangelo, Op. 145a		No. 4: Separation
7. Suite on Words by Michelangelo, Op. 145a		No. 5: Wrath
8. Suite on Words by Michelangelo, Op. 145a		No. 6: Dante
9. Suite on Words by Michelangelo, Op. 145a		No. 8: Creation
10. Suite on Words by Michelangelo, Op. 145a		No. 9: Night
11. Suite on Words by Michelangelo, Op. 145a		No. 10: Death
12. Suite on Words by Michelangelo, Op. 145a		No. 11: Immortality
13. Novorossiisk Chimes, Op. 111b

Ever the humorist, Shostakovich delighted in placing allusions to the works of himself and other composers in his Fifteenth Symphony: in addition to the cryptic references to his own music, it includes an outburst of Rossini’s William Tell Overture in the first movement (rehearsal figure 12); allusions to Mikhail Glinka and Gustav Mahler; and the use of Richard Wagner’s Fate leitmotif from the Ring Cycle. No humour with the orchestral version of Michelangelo cycle profoundly personal, deeply felt, close to immortality? (a work commemorating the 500th anniversary of Italian genius in 1975. And finally the TV synchronization anthem of the TV networks of the former USSR, being more easily anchored in human memory than the Kindertotenlieder.

Awards: 5 by Diapason

-

250 334
